captions.text:
Some day, indie games, you and I are going
to have to draw up a little constitution and

decide how long is too long to be in early
fucking access. I made a vow to stop reviewing

games that are still in oily excess because
anything I criticise can get fixed before

the final release and then my review just
has to dangle there from the internet looking

all wrong and stupid like a decent human being
in a Republican controlled Senate. Plus it

leads to situations like when I half-arsedly
reviewed Fortnite while it was still in twirly

axis, little realising it would soon become
the world&#39;s third most popular form of human

communication. But now I have a new problem,
because sometimes games stay in early access

the whole time they&#39;re in the popular Zeitgeist
so by the time I review it no one cares and

have all moved onto John Madden&#39;s Felching
Simulator 2020. Black Mesa was announced fifteen

years ago and been in early access for five.
I assume they&#39;ve been waiting until the kitschy

retro factor kicks in since they missed the
first chance to strike while the panty was

wet. As a critic this has been a right pinecone
up my perineum. Back when I first played Black

Mesa in those wonderful days before all sense
left the Earth I had tons of shit to critic

about but they kept throwing up the early
access card like a crucifix to a vampire.

&quot;Hey, where are the Xen levels?&quot; &quot;EARLY ACCESS!&quot;
Hssssss. &quot;Hey, the enemy soldiers seem a bit

too accurate-&quot; &quot;EARLY ACCESS!&quot; &quot;Oh for fuck&#39;s
sake.&quot; And now I&#39;m roundly miffed to see that

the release version of Black Mesa is really
fucking polished. Which is all anyone should

expect, since they&#39;ve been polishing it for
so fucking long there&#39;s a six inch layer of

crystallised Mr. Sheen around the thing. But
let&#39;s take a step back. Black Mesa is a fan-made

remake of the seminal 90&#39;s PC shooter, narrative
action game tentpole and all around ball of

chunky cuddles Half-Life, made in the Half-Life
2 Source engine. You see, when Half-Life 2

came out Valve put out a version of Half-Life
in the Source engine but it was just a copy

paste of the assets, so some disappointed
fellow said &quot;Hey, wouldn&#39;t it be great if

this was an actual remake of Half-Life in
the style of Half-Life 2 with fully updated

graphics and level design?&quot; And someone else
said, &quot;Yes, that would be great. Hop to it.&quot;

And thus was decided the next fifteen years
of that poor fucker&#39;s life. Now, my philosophy

brain reminds me that I disapprove of this
kind of thing.

Part of the value of art is as a capsule of
the styles and attitudes of its era, dragging

an old classic into the present and forcing
it to chase new trends is a cycle that never

stops, the Source engine is itself pretty
old and crusty at this point and Black Mesa

will now need to be remade again in Unreal
Engine 4 with VR support and oh bollocks probably

shouldn&#39;t put the idea in their heads. But
on the other hand, my down-to-earth brain

points out A) this is the fucking modern games
industry we&#39;re talking about, where they don&#39;t

even apply backwards compatability to their
baseball caps, so in a few years this might

well be the only way we CAN play Half-Life,
and B) Black Mesa gives me lovely wobbly feelings

in my tummy tum because Half-Life is my boo.
If you want to know how Black Mesa would be

for someone who&#39;s never played the original
then I haven&#39;t got the least fucking idea,

go to Timmy Tween Twitchstreamer and pay him
a hundred bits to answer that question if

he can stop sucking Mountain Dew from his
mum&#39;s titties for five seconds. I&#39;m more familiar

with the layout of Half-Life than I am with
that of female genitalia, and Black Mesa follows

it closely, so it&#39;s all that lovely pacing
and narrative gameplay but now with the beer
goggles taken off.

Everything&#39;s crisper, the guns are more satisfying,
the characters have a little more character,

the environments make a little more sense
with not so many sewage runoff pipes outflowing

inexplicably into people&#39;s offices. I note
we still haven&#39;t solved the issue of everyone

looking the same. The original Half-Life only
had four different scientist models but they

were very different, running a spectrum between
Albert Einstein and Sidney Poitier. Now it&#39;s

more like twelve very slight variations on
the same face, and not just the scientists,

the security guards and the soldiers have
the same ones, and all with the same body

type so it&#39;s like the facility was taken over
by a tribe of very generic Oompa-Loompas.

See, there were notes of silliness in the
original Half-Life that one forgave of a janky

90s shooter but which are thrown into sharp
relief by a more modern, realistic tone. Obliging

the player to press crouch while jumping in
order to jump over slightly higher things

is in retrospect a pretty janky workaround
for an engine limitation, you&#39;d expect some

kind of mantling physics these days. And it
suddenly seems odd that no one Gordon Freeman

meets as he fights his way out of the doomed
facility wants to come with him.

Quick, Gordon, rescue teams are meeting us
on the surface, I&#39;ll open this door for you.

Let me know how it works out. What, me? No,
I couldn&#39;t possibly come too, there might

be something you need to crouch under or a
one foot high obstacle. It&#39;s probably safest

for me to hang out in this alien infested
corridor, maybe stick my underpants on my

head and try to live among the parasite monsters
like Diane fuckin&#39; Fossey. But let&#39;s leave

the bulk of the game to one side. After all,
a remake of a good thing still being good

doesn&#39;t score any points &#39;cos it had to copy
its homework. The real challenge was the Xen

levels. For most of the time Slack Mavis was
in early access it just awkwardly stopped

right after you jump into the portal to the
alien realm and cut to credits after two or

three seconds of the Doctor Who opening titles,
because what the fuck do you do with Xen,

the notoriously unpopular final chapter of
an otherwise timeless classic? You&#39;ve got

to at least try to make it good if you&#39;re
already committed to making changes, you can&#39;t

throw out the Einstein scientist and then
preserve the pile of shit at the end for posterity.

Black Mesa&#39;s Xen is three or four times longer
than the original, which I&#39;m not sure is the

solution I&#39;d have gone for. &quot;Oh, you don&#39;t
want your broccoli? Well here&#39;s three times

as much, bitch, and if you don&#39;t learn to
like it I&#39;m going to start pushing it up your nose.&quot;

I suppose having worked on it for years they
wanted to prove they weren&#39;t Duke Nukem Forevering

that whole time, and that is most certainly
proved. The cosmic vistas are spectacular,

every inch of effort is on display, and while
it is overlong and the quality has its dips,

some bits are pretty forgettable and some
chug along like the early morning hangover

shits, there&#39;s enough of a sense of wonder
about it that I wasn&#39;t unengaged. Trouble

is, I don&#39;t think it addresses the actual
issue with Xen - we just spent umpteen hours

tactically combatting our way through an ever-evolving
narrative about a research facility disaster

and military cover-up and this Metroid meets
American McGee&#39;s Alice bad acid trip at a

children&#39;s ball pit full of tricky platforming
and bullet spongey bosses doesn&#39;t feel like

a payoff for what was set up. And with its
lurching shift of tone and handful of hitherto

unused movement and puzzle mechanics Neo-Xen
might as well be a different game altogether.

In summary, Half-Life was a handsome, intelligent
and smartly dressed man who was inexplicably

wearing one bright green wellington boot.
I don&#39;t think the solution was to put on the
other wellington boot.
